There really needs to be an 'in between' rating system available, but, alas...
As a Bioshock game, it's horrendous; there are no open world elements, the storyline in the base game has nothing to do with the original two games except for a short scene at the end (the DLC kinda shoehorns in a connection of sorts but it's extremely unnecessary), the already-dumbed-down-from-SS2 RPG elements have been dumbed down even more, the combat is in no ways as dynamic as they made it seem like it would be in the early gameplay demos, and it doesn't nearly have as hard an impact as Bioshock 1 or even 2 did with its commentary on society with its simple "racism is bad get your head out of the clouds (lol)" message.
Also the fact that it was the last game Irrational made before 'restructuring' into a fucking small-scaled almost indie-level developer on Fuhrer Levine's orders. Because firing 90% of your employees on a whim after making bank on an extremely succesful FPS totally isn't shifty at all!
But if you ignore the fact that it's apparently a Bioshock game, it's an alright game. The environment, although a bit samey in areas, is decently diverse and extremely colorful, the story is decent and has enough twists and turns to keep you intrigued, the binary morality choices, while extremely basic, do add a slight bit of replayability, and the combat, while enemies start to get quite bullet-spongey near the end of the game, is competent enough to be enjoyable.
Is it worth 30 dollars?
Not really.
Is it a fun game?
Mostly.
It just isn't a Bioshock game.
But thankfully, we have System Shock 3 and the System Shock 1 remake in the future, so we can just, ignore this game's existence and focus on those, yeah?
Yeah.

It really is a wonderful game; a great swansong for the franchise. I'd recommend playing the first game before this one, although it really isn't necessary. Infinite is it's own story, but set in the same world as the original.

What really sets these Bioshock apart from other shooters is the atmosphere.  I think Infinite excels at this even more than the original because of the more realistic romanticized setting of 190X America. I remember getting lost is the first few 'no combat' stages like I was playing some sort of walking simulator.

It's the story that really makes this game. Combat, though enjoyable, takes a back seat to the plot. There's only a handful of open combat stages, which I felt to be the only negetive, only because it limits the experience with the large assortment of upgradable weapons and powers.

I also enjoyed having a non-combat, support companion. The thing I hate most from AI team shooters (/cough Mass Effect) is that the AI spends most of its time blocking line of sight rather than engaging the enemy. Elizabeth, on the other hand, throws me ammo and stays the hell out of my way. I couldn't ask for more. I like how she takes cover and moves around too, even though she's can't be hurt.

Infinite is also one of the few games that I can easily recommend the DLC. "Clash in the Clouds" is a great sandbox for trying out all the weapons without fear of ammo or progression (you can only hold two weapons at a time). I almost suggest playing it before the main game, but it would spoil the story. "Burial at Sea" is the final chapter of Bioshock centered around Elizabeth. It wraps up the franchise nicely, though I wouldn't bother unless you've played the original game.

Overall I recommend Bioshock Infinite to just about anyone, especially story-rich shooter fans. If you enjoyed the original, you definitely owe it to yourself to pick this one up.

I enjoyed this game like no-other bioshock game, as it was such an amazing concept.

Bioshock Infinite é um desses jogos que te prendem pela beleza e pela trama. Os cenários são belíssimos, com uma caracterização de época mesclado com elementos modernos de forma bem interessante. Inclusive preste atenção na música. Você vai reconhecer algumas delas. E mais para o final do jogo tem até uma explicação ótima para isso (basta explorar bem os cenários pra descobrir).  ;-)

Já a história vai crescendo ao longo do tempo e ganhando rumos que você nem imagina. O final então.... É simplesmente genial! Daquele que você tem jogar mais de uma vez (ou procurar ou vídeo na Internet) pra ver se é aquilo mesmo que você entendeu.  :-)

Então, se você gosta de FPS com uma boa trama e onde você tem que pensar ao invés de sair simplesmente atirando em tudo, recomendo fortemente. Inclusive a versão para GNU/Linux está ótima.
Uma das melhores histórias em jogos

Bioshock Infinite takes the foundation of the first two games and rockets above them. The story is incredibly compelling, with twists and turns working their way to an ending that will leave you speechless. The voice acting that brings the story to life is masterfully done, and the writing will give you a reason to care about the things going on, something the previous Bioshock games had been missing. The atmosphere offers a combination of science fiction and alternate history and is so immersive that you sometimes feel like you've actually stumbled into another world. The gameplay is exciting, and unlike the previous games, remains somewhat challenging until the end. This is one of my favorite games, and regardless of whether you liked the previous two Bioshock games or never played them, this game offers an amazing experience.

Bioshock: Infinite is a great entertaining game. The storyline is magnificent and it really takes over you after you've played the start. The graphics are beautiful and the makers of Bioshock did yet again great work of creating a beautiful world.
There isn't as much of to explore as in Bioshock and Bioshock 2 but the story makes up for it.

4.5/5

[h1]It isn't just a game - it's an [b]Art.[/b][/h1]

[i]As an artwork [u]masterpiece[/u] [b]Bioshock Infinite[/b] satisfies my most important need - it shares an exciting deep story.
I won't lie if I say this game copes with storytelling task just brilliant, because it is true.
When I played it for the first time I simply didn't want to make even a short break to eat, I was too fascinated by ingame characters and the narrative. I've always been asking myself - "What happens next?"
[b][u]Irrational Games[/u][/b] shared a mature story with amazing plot full of twists causing a wave of uncontrollable emotions. Developers  had no purpose to keep us shooting stuff to simply make the game longer, their key was the story and I felt I wanted more of this, much more. But I had no hopes until I found out that it has 2 DLCs. I can't even describe how much my delightedly stupid stunned face was happy at the moment. This game surely brought me the biggest amount of describable emotions in my whole gaming experience.
I'm not even sure if it was correct of me to call it [b][u]a game[/u][/b], I think it should be called [b][u]an event[/u][/b] in the entire worldwide gaming development.[/i]

[i]Honestly, I could share all pros and cons, but I don't see any sense in that since I'm rating it 10 of 10 even after 4 years since release. So great it is at all possible aspects from my point of view. I'm trying to find out what I dislike about this game - nothing comes up to my head. I'm sure somebody can tell you - this thing or that thing in this game is bad, but I can't. I tried though.
I've collected all possible achievements and still want to replay it + I can barely name 10 games that have such a good replayability.[i]

[i]It's a story that consumed me completely and made me want to say only 3 words - [b][u]Give Me More![/u][/b][/i]
